author: Natalie Wickman
title: The Marcus Corp. selling Hotel Phillips in Kansas City
text:
Enlarge The Hotel Phillips in Kansas City, Mo. It reopened in 2001 after a $20 million renovation. The Marcus Corp. has agreed to sell Hotel Phillips in Kansas City, Mo., to an affiliate of Arbor Lodging Partners, the company announced today. The sale and transition of management for Hotel Phillips is slated for Sept. 1. Milwaukee-based Marcus Corp. (NYSE: MCS) has owned it for 14 years and financed an extensive renovation during that time. Arbor Lodging Partners is a Chicago-based owner and manager of hotels nationwide that makes debt and equity investments in hospitality properties. “The decision to sell the Hotel Phillips is consistent with our overall corporate strategy of constantly evaluating each of our owned hotels to ensure we are maximizing shareholder value, while also focusing on growth through new management contracts,” said Gregory Marcus , president and chief executive officer of The Marcus Corp., in a statement. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. “We consider this a highly strategic opportunity to acquire this beautiful historic hotel in Kansas City and to contribute to the future growth of the downtown area," said Vamsi Bonthala , chief executive officer of Arbor Lodging Partners, in a statement. “As with other historic properties in our portfolio, we are planning a comprehensive renovation and the hotel will be managed by NVN Hotels, our hotel management affiliate.” In its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report July 23, Marcus Corp. said it recorded a one-time after-tax impairment charge related to one of its hotel properties that reduced net income by 6 cents per share in the quarter. The company did not identify the property. Analysts from Robert W. Baird & Co. Inc. in Milwaukee said in a note issued July 27 that they believed the charge suggested the impending sale of one of the company's hotels. A company official did not immediately respond for comment. The Baird analysts said they would view the hotel sale positively, since Marcus could redeploy proceeds into theater acquisitions or development.
